overview_of_class: The purpose of this course is to expose students to the somewhat lost musicals and the greatest hits of music theatre in the era commonly referred to as the Golden Age of musicals. Through class discussion, lecture, listening exams, and screenings, the students will leave learning over 100 songs and the history of some of the most important musicals of the 20th century and how those musicals forever shaped the art of music theatre.
name: Residence-Linked Seminar - VI (Literature and Fine Arts)
topic: Musical Theatre Reportoire: The Golden Age, 1940-1
subject: GEN_LA

overview_of_class: To introduce students to the analysis of great movies through the lens of Taoism, Buddhism and Zen. In particular, assigned readings and critical viewing of film classics will illustrate how principles of these three ancient wisdom traditions can be applied to construct a unique theoretical framework for the study of great movies. This analysis will help students to understand how ethical and moral problems arise, the extent to which related decisions are a matter of choice, and the consequences that evolve from interaction of values and choices of individuals, societies and cultures.
name: Residence-Linked Seminar - VI (Literature and Fine Arts)
topic: Popcorn Buddhism: How to Watch Great Movies and At
subject: GEN_LA

overview_of_class: In this course we will study and practice multiple forms of food writing, including food memoir, critical restaurant reviews, recipe essays, and analyses of family and cultural foodways. Course will also include a hands-on culinary component and will utilize the kitchen in Elder R.C. for a cooking demonstration with a chef and for students to test recipes for the recipe essay assignment.
name: Residence-Linked Seminar - VI (Literature and Fine Arts)
topic: Table to Page: The Art and Culture of Food Writing
subject: GEN_LA
